header:
import Mathlib

open Function Nat

-- (fun n : ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ 2 ^ ‚åä(n + 2) / 2‚åã‚Çä + 2 ^ ‚åä(n + 1) / 2‚åã‚Çä - 2)

/--
Given a finite string $S$ of symbols $X$ and $O$, we write $\Delta(S)$ for the number of $X$'s in $S$ minus the number of $O$'s. For example, $\Delta(XOOXOOX)=-1$. We call a string $S$ \emph{balanced} if every substring $T$ of (consecutive symbols of) $S$ has $-2 \leq \Delta(T) \leq 2$. Thus, $XOOXOOX$ is not balanced, since it contains the substring $OOXOO$. Find, with proof, the number of balanced strings of length $n$.
-/
name: putnam_1996_b5
formal_statement:
theorem putnam_1996_b5
    (n : ‚Ñï)
    (Œî : (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñ§À£) ‚Üí Fin n ‚Üí Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñ§)
    (balanced : (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñ§À£) ‚Üí Prop)
    (hŒî : ‚àÄ S, ‚àÄ a b, a ‚â§ b ‚Üí Œî S a b = ‚àë i in Finset.Icc a b, (S i : ‚Ñ§))
    (hbalanced : ‚àÄ S, balanced S ‚Üî ‚àÄ a b, a ‚â§ b ‚Üí |Œî S a b| ‚â§ 2) :
    {S : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñ§À£ | balanced S}.ncard = ((fun n : ‚Ñï ‚Ü¶ 2 ^ ‚åä(n + 2) / 2‚åã‚Çä + 2 ^ ‚åä(n + 1) / 2‚åã‚Çä - 2) : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñï ) n :=
  by
informal_statement: Given a finite string $S$ of symbols $X$ and $O$, we write $\Delta(S)$ for the number of $X$'s in $S$ minus the number of $O$'s. For example, $\Delta(XOOXOOX)=-1$. We call a string $S$ \emph{balanced} if every substring $T$ of (consecutive symbols of) $S$ has $-2 \leq \Delta(T) \leq 2$. Thus, $XOOXOOX$ is not balanced, since it contains the substring $OOXOO$. Find, with proof, the number of balanced strings of length $n$.
informal_solution: Show that the number of balanced strings of length $n$ is $3 \cdot 2^{n/2}-2$ if $n$ is even, and $2^{(n+1)/2}-2$ if $n$ is odd.

/--
Let $A$ be a positive real number. What are the possible values of $\sum_{j=0}^\infty x_j^2$, given that $x_0,x_1,\ldots$ are positive numbers for which $\sum_{j=0}^\infty x_j=A$?
-/
name: putnam_2000_a1
formal_statement:
theorem putnam_2000_a1
(A : ‚Ñù)
(Apos : A > 0)
: {S : ‚Ñù |
    ‚àÉ x : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù,
      (‚àÄ j : ‚Ñï, x j > 0) ‚àß
      (‚àë' j : ‚Ñï, x j) = A ‚àß
      (‚àë' j : ‚Ñï, (x j) ^ 2) = S}
  = ((fun A : ‚Ñù => Set.Ioo 0 (A ^ 2)) : ‚Ñù ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù ) A := by
informal_statement: Let $A$ be a positive real number. What are the possible values of $\sum_{j=0}^\infty x_j^2$, given that $x_0,x_1,\ldots$ are positive numbers for which $\sum_{j=0}^\infty x_j=A$?
informal_solution: Show that the possible values comprise the interval $(0,A^2)$.

header:
import Mathlib

open Filter Topology

-- Note: uses (‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) instead of (Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
-- {p : Polynomial ‚Ñù | p.degree = 2 ‚àß (‚àÉ r1 r2 : ‚Ñù, r1 ‚â† r2 ‚àß p.eval r1 = 0 ‚àß p.eval r2 = 0)}
/--
Find all real polynomials $p(x)$ of degree $n \geq 2$ for which there exist real numbers $r_1<r_2<\cdots<r_n$ such that
\begin{enumerate}
\item $p(r_i)=0, \qquad i=1,2,\dots,n$, and
\item $p'(\frac{r_i+r_{i+1}}{2})=0 \qquad i=1,2,\dots,n-1$,
\end{enumerate}
where $p'(x)$ denotes the derivative of $p(x)$.
-/
name: putnam_1991_a3
formal_statement:
theorem putnam_1991_a3
  (p : Polynomial ‚Ñù)
  (n : ‚Ñï)
  (hn : n = p.degree)
  (hge : n ‚â• 2) :
  p ‚àà (({p : Polynomial ‚Ñù | p.degree = 2 ‚àß (‚àÉ r1 r2 : ‚Ñù, r1 ‚â† r2 ‚àß p.eval r1 = 0 ‚àß p.eval r2 = 0)}) : Set (Polynomial ‚Ñù) ) ‚Üî
    (‚àÉ r : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù, (‚àÄ i : Fin (n - 1), r i < r (i + 1)) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ i : Fin n, p.eval (r i) = 0) ‚àß
    (‚àÄ i : Fin (n - 1), (Polynomial.derivative p).eval ((r i + r (i + 1)) / 2) = 0)) := by
informal_solution: Show that the real polynomials with the required property are exactly those that are of degree $2$ with $2$ distinct real zeros.

/--
Let $A$, $B$, $C$, and $D$ be four distinct points for which every circle through $A$ and $B$ intersects every circle through $C$ and $D$. Prove that $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$ are either collinear (all lying on the same line) or cocyclic (all lying on the same circle).
-/
name: putnam_1965_b6
formal_statement:
theorem putnam_1965_b6
    (A B C D : EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2))
    (S : Set (EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2)))

    (through : (‚Ñù √ó (EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2))) ‚Üí (EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 2)) ‚Üí Prop)
    (through_def : through = fun (r, P) => fun Q => dist P Q = r)
    (hABCD : ‚àÄ r s : ‚Ñù, ‚àÄ P Q,
      through (r, P) A ‚àß through (r, P) B ‚àß through (s, Q) C ‚àß through (s, Q) D ‚Üí
      ‚àÉ I, through (r, P) I ‚àß through (s, Q) I) :
    Collinear ‚Ñù S ‚à® ‚àÉ r : ‚Ñù, ‚àÉ P, ‚àÄ Q ‚àà S, through (r, P) Q :=
  by

-- fun (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (n : ‚Ñï) (x : ‚Ñù) (t : ‚Ñù) ‚Ü¶ (x - t) ^ (n - 1) * (f t) / ((n - 1)! * t ^ n)
/--
Find an integral formula (i.e., a function $z$ such that $y(x) = \int_{1}^{x} z(t) dt$) for the solution of the differential equation $$\delta (\delta - 1) (\delta - 2) \cdots (\delta - n + 1) y = f(x)$$ with the initial conditions $y(1) = y'(1) = \cdots = y^{(n-1)}(1) = 0$, where $n \in \mathbb{N}$, $f$ is continuous for all $x \ge 1$, and $\delta$ denotes $x\frac{d}{dx}$.

    (P : ‚Ñï ‚Üí (‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) ‚Üí (‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù))
    (hP : P 0 = id ‚àß ‚àÄ i y, P (i + 1) y = P i (fun x ‚Ü¶ x * deriv y x - i * y x))
    (n : ‚Ñï)
    (hn : 0 < n)
    (f y : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)

/--
A Dyck $n$-path is a lattice path of $n$ upsteps $(1,1)$ and $n$ downsteps $(1,-1)$ that starts at the origin $O$ and never dips below the $x$-axis. A return is a maximal sequence of contiguous downsteps that terminates on the $x$-axis. Show that there is a one-to-one correspondence between the Dyck $n$-paths with no return of even length and the Dyck $(n-1)$-paths.
-/
name: putnam_2003_a5
formal_statement:

(n : ‚Ñï) (npos : n > 0)
(dyckpath : (m : ‚Ñï) ‚Üí Set ((Fin (2 * m)) ‚Üí ‚Ñ§))
(hdyckpath : dyckpath = fun m ‚Ü¶ {p |
      range p ‚äÜ {-1, 1} ‚àß ‚àë k, p k = 0 ‚àß ‚àÄ j, ‚àë k, ite (k ‚â§ j) (p k) 0 ‚â• 0})
(noevenreturn : (m : ‚Ñï) ‚Üí Set ((Fin (2 * m)) ‚Üí ‚Ñ§))
(hnoevenreturn : noevenreturn = fun m ‚Ü¶ {p |
      ¬¨‚àÉ i j, i < j ‚àß p i = 1 ‚àß (‚àÄ k ‚àà Ioc i j, p i = -1) ‚àß
            Even (j.1 - i.1) ‚àß ‚àë k, ite (k ‚â§ j) (p k) 0 = 0})
      : ‚àÉ f : ((Fin (2 * n)) ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) ‚Üí (Fin (2 * (n - 1)) ‚Üí ‚Ñ§),
            ‚àÄ y ‚àà dyckpath (n - 1), ‚àÉ! x, x ‚àà dyckpath n ‚à© noevenreturn n ‚àß f x = y := by

(f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù)

informal_statement:
Let $f$ be an infinitely differentiable real-valued function defined on the real numbers. If
\[
f\left( \frac{1}{n} \right) = \frac{n^2}{n^2 + 1}, \qquad n = 1, 2, 3, \dots,

\end{cases}
\]

For a nonnegative integer $n$ and a strictly increasing sequence of real numbers $t_0,t_1,\dots,t_n$, let $f(t)$ be the corresponding real-valued function defined for $t \geq t_0$ by the following properties:
\begin{enumerate}
\item[(a)] $f(t)$ is continuous for $t \geq t_0$, and is twice differentiable for all $t>t_0$ other than $t_1,\dots,t_n$;
\item[(b)] $f(t_0)=1/2$;
\item[(c)] $\lim_{t \to t_k^+} f'(t)=0$ for $0 \leq k \leq n$;
\item[(d)] For $0 \leq k \leq n-1$, we have $f''(t)=k+1$ when $t_k<t<t_{k+1}$, and $f''(t)=n+1$ when $t>t_n$.
\end{enumerate}
Considering all choices of $n$ and $t_0,t_1,\dots,t_n$ such that $t_k \geq t_{k-1}+1$ for $1 \leq k \leq n$, what is the least possible value of $T$ for which $f(t_0+T)=2023$?
-/

    (tne : ‚Ñï ‚Üí (‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) ‚Üí Set ‚Ñù)

    IsLeast
    {(T : ‚Ñù) | 0 ‚â§ T ‚àß ‚àÉ (n : ‚Ñï) (ts : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù),
      ‚àÄ k : Fin n, ts (k.1 + 1) ‚â• ts k.1 + 1 ‚àß
      ContinuousOn f (Set.Ici (ts 0)) ‚àß
      ContDiffOn ‚Ñù 1 f (tne n ts) ‚àß
      DifferentiableOn ‚Ñù (derivWithin f (tne n ts)) (tne n ts) ‚àß
      f (ts 0) = 0.5 ‚àß
      (‚àÄ k : Fin (n + 1),
        Tendsto (derivWithin f (tne n ts)) (ùìù[>] (ts k.1)) (ùìù 0)) ‚àß
      (‚àÄ k : Fin n,
        ‚àÄ t ‚àà Set.Ioo (ts k.1) (ts (k.1 + 1)),
          iteratedDerivWithin 2 f (tne n ts) t = k.1 + 1) ‚àß
      (‚àÄ t > ts n,
        iteratedDerivWithin 2 f (tne n ts) t = n + 1) ‚àß
